Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating the regulatory Mechanisms of Plant Thimet Oligopeptidases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plant diseases result in multi-billion dollar crop loss worldwide. Salicylic acid (SA) is a vital plant hormone that plays a central role in immune signaling and activation of defense responses. The hormone elicits a cascade of effects that regulates gene expression and protein activity. The project explores the means in which the activity and protein-interactions of two salicylic acid binding proteins, thimet oligopeptidase 1 and 2 (TOP1 & TOP2) are regulated. The research project will be conducted at RIKEN institute in Yohokama, Japan. The project will be a collaborative effort with Dr. Ken Shirasu, who is at the forefront of research pertaining to plant immunity and salicylic acid. Dr. Shirasu belongs to the renowned RIKEN research institute which houses a state-of-the-art research center with all the equipment and facilities needed to conduct the research project.

The project will investigate the enzymatic activity and multimer formation of TOP1 and TOP2. Evidence suggests that TOP activity is governed by redox-sensitive bonds; however, the extent and dynamics of the redox-regulated and hormone-regulated peptide processing of TOP1 and TOP2 have yet to be determined. The objective of the project is to investigate the key components of the proteins that dictate the perceptivity of the peptidases towards SA and the cellular redox state. In order to do this, the activities and oligomerization of TOPs and various TOP deletion/substitution mutants will be assessed under different SA concentrations and reducing/oxidizing environments. The findings will further our understanding of a potential hub of hormone-controlled and redox-regulated peptidase processing in plants. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researching components of plant immunity and redox regulation is imperative to further our understanding of plant defenses. Thimet oligopeptidase 1 (TOP1) and thimet oligopeptidase 2 (TOP2) are two proteins found to bind to the plant hormone salicylic acid (SA). SA acts as a signaling molecule which regulates plant immunity. The hormone functions in plant development and abiotic stress responses. SA changes the redox state of the cell and modulates the activity of various proteins. TOPs have been previously found to be redox-sensitive. My goal was to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms of TOP1 and TOP2 to further our understanding of redox-sensitive peptidases.  

Post-translational modifications (PTMs) are major forms of regulation on protein activity. Recent evidence suggest that TOPs are modified based on the redox state of the cell. My work successfully detected modifications of TOPs. With collaborators, a protocol was developed to determine what specific regions of TOPs are involved in the modification. My study also examined whether the interactions of TOPs with proteins are manipulated by the redox modulators. The outcome strongly suggests that protein-protein interactions with TOPs are redox-regulated. To follow up with these results, I identified regions within the proteins that may dictate the peptidases’ redox sensitivity. Another aim of the project was to determine which regions of these proteins are imperative to their function. In order to assess their function, the activities of the proteins were monitored by detecting the breakdown of peptides. Specific portions of the proteins were mutated and the integrity of the activities were investigated. My work identified regions of TOP1 and TOP2 that may be critical to the function of the proteins.

My research was done in Dr. Ken Shirasu’s plant immunity laboratory at RIKEN Yokohama, Japan. It was an honor to work in his laboratory group. The EAPSI program granted me the opportunity to work in a state of the art research center with many colleagues. The members of Dr. Shirasu’s research group were extremely helpful. I not only consider them my collaborators, but also my friends. The program allowed me to develop fantastic relationships and provided me with the means to conduct research in an international setting. It was an extremely rewarding research and cultural experience. I thank the NSF, the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science, and my host, Dr. Shirasu, for this fantastic experience.
